audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 9, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Books for Unit 8 and Unit 9.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Community Workers.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Listen to the sounds.
<visual: show articulation video for r-controlled vowel /ûr/>

This is the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/. The spellings "i-r," "e-r," and "u-r" stand for the /ûr/ sounds. What sounds does the spelling "i-r" make in the word "bird?" <pause> "/ûr/." Listen as your teacher continues with more r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ûr/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the r-Controlled Vowel /ûr/, let’s blend some words with r-Controlled Vowel /ûr/ and other sounds to practice what we've learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/heeennn/, hen. /hûûûrrr/, her. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about workers' unions. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. strike <pause>, banner <pause>, picket line <pause>, sign <pause> workers. Look at the workers in the picture. What are they doing?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about workers' unions. The word is negotiate. Negotiate means to try to agree on something by having a discussion about it.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, negotiate>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, satisfies>

audio.transcription: Audio 1: Now listen to “Fighting for Fair Working Conditions”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words negotiate and satisfies>

audio.transcription: Audio 2: Do you have any wonderings or questions about workers' unions? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 9 Student Book. The title of this story is "Turkeys Together!” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Turkeys Together! The picture shows two animals that live on a farm—a horse and a turkey. Turkey is a type of bird.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: exercise. Exercise is movement or a physical activity that is good for your body. I ride my bike for exercise. What do you do for exercise? Tell your partner about it.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, exercise>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that names how Tyler feels once he learns about Thanksgiving.
What do the turkeys do for exercise? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Tyler says that being healthy is the most important gift. What does he mean? Do you agree? Why or why not?
Why is it important to exercise? How else do you keep your body healthy?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write about what you are thankful for and why. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 9, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 9.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Turkeys Together!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Audio 1: Listen as I say the following word: mat
Audio 2: Say the word mat without the beginning sound /m/. What's the new word? <pause> at
Audio 3: Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Audio 1: Now let's delete the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say the following word: same
Audio 2: Say the word same without the ending sound /m/. What's the new word? <pause> say
Audio 3: Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

This is the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/. The spellings "i-r," "e-r," and "u-r" stand for the /ûr/ sounds. What sounds does the spelling "i-r" make in the word "bird?" <pause> "/ûr/." Listen as your teacher continues with more r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ûr/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the r-Controlled Vowel /ûr/, let’s blend some words with r-Controlled Vowel /ûr/ and other sounds to practice what we've learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/heeennn/, hen. /hûûûrrr/, her. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: all, away, better, by, change.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word all. Say the word with me. All. Which sounds do you hear in all? /ô/ /l/. Blend the sounds together.
Spell the word with me: a-l-l. The word "all" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: away, better, by, change.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about government agencies. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. inspectors <pause>, box <pause>, uniform <pause>, food. Look at the inspectors in the picture. What are they doing?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about government agencies. The word is reliable. Someone who is reliable is trustworthy or dependable.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, reliable>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, establishes>

audio.transcription: Audio 1: Now listen to “Government Agencies – Ready to Serve”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words reliable and establishes>

audio.transcription: Audio 2: Do you have any wonderings or questions about government agencies? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 9 Student Book. The title of this text is "A Bird Debate: Who Should Be America’s National Bird?” Point to each word as you read the title with me: A Bird Debate: Who Should Be America’s National Bird? A debate is a discussion in which people express different opinions about a topic or an issue.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: discussion. To have a discussion is to talk about something in order to make a decision or share ideas. We had a discussion about what to have for lunch. What is something you might have a discussion about with a parent or family member?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, discussion>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that names what the turkey uses to defend, or protect, itself.
How is a turkey’s call different than an eagle’s call? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What kind of information are Eagle and Turkey presenting during this discussion? Why is this information important to their debate?
Which bird do you think won the debate? Give a reason to support your answer.
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Name the bird that won the debate and list two or three facts for support. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 9, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 9.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Bird Debate: Who Should Be America’s National Bird?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/. The spellings "i-r," "e-r," and "u-r" stand for the /ûr/ sounds. What sounds does the spelling "i-r" make in the word "bird?" <pause> "/ûr/." Listen as your teacher continues with more r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ûr/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the r-Controlled Vowel /ûr/, let’s blend some words with r-Controlled Vowel /ûr/ and other sounds to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with er.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with ir.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word fin. <pause> Change the letter n to ro to make the r- controlled ir spelling. What word did you make?
Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word fin <pause>. Now change fin to fir. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with r-controlled vowel /ûr/ and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with r-controlled vowel /ûr/. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word bird. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word bird>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: girl/her, turn/first.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs girl/her, turn/first>

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus
Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 9, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 9.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
Let's review inflectional endings. Inflectional endings change the tense of a verb, or action word. The "ing" ending shows that the action is happening now.
Some base words require spelling changes before adding the ending, such as doubling the final consonant or dropping the final "e."
Listen as I read the following word: "stir." Before adding inflectional ending "ing" to "stir," double the final consonant "r."
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: stir stir+r+ing stirring (show "ing" in red font) >

audio.transcription: Now add the "inflectional ending "ing to the end "stir." What is the new word?
stirring.
Listen as I read the following word: "turn." Add the inflectional ending "ing" to the end of "turn." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word turn and the phonics/syllable card "ing" across from it>

audio.transcription: turning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word turn and the phonics/syllable card "ing" across from it, under them, show the word "turning">

audio.transcription: Practice adding inflectional ending "ing" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words hop, curl, sit, eat, twirl, and sleep each across from the phonics/syllable card ing>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/. The spellings "i-r," "e-r," and "u-r" stand for the /ûr/ sounds. What sounds does the spelling "i-r" make in the word "bird?" <pause> "/ûr/." Listen as your teacher continues with more r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: done, even, found, learn, only>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word done. Say the word with me. Done. The word "done" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me: d-o-n-e. The letter "o" makes the /u/ sound in the word "done."
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: even, found, learn, only.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word germ.
Now write the word hurt.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
girl
first
sparked
turning
farmer

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 9 Student Book. The title of this text is "Vote!" Point to each word as you read the title with me: Vote! The text is formatted in short lines. This is a poem. A vote is a way to express, or show, your choice. Read the poem. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the poem with r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Audio 1: Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.

Audio 2: The first sentence is: I found a spot of dirt on my shirt. Say the sentence with me: I found a spot of dirt on my shirt. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.
Audio 3: The second sentence is: Mom shows Jane how to curl her hair. Say the sentence with me: Mom shows Jane how to curl her hair. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Audio 4: Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 9, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 9.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Whisper read the story Vote!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Let’s review inflectional ending "ing." Inflectional endings are suffixes. A suffix is a word part that may be added to the end of a word. It can change the word’s meaning and part of speech.
Listen as I read the following word: "burst." Add the inflectional ending "ing" to the end of "burst." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "burst" and the phonics/syllable card for "ing">

audio.transcription: "bursting." <pause> "Bursting" is the present-tense form of the verb "burst." The inflectional ending "ing" is added to a base word to make it present-tense.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "burst" and the phonics/syllable card for "ing", under them, show the word "bursting">

audio.transcription: Practice adding the inflectional ending "ing" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show two columns of words: in the left column, show the words "burn," "read," "shop," "enter" and in the right column, show the phonics/syllable cards for "ing" across from each word>

audio.transcription: Look at these words. Let's read the words together: sister, verb, serving, germ, nerve, clever, artist, sharpen, star, market, farm, shark. Now look at these two categories. This is the word spring. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put sister under? <pause> Yes, sister goes in the er- category because the word sister ends with -er. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show words sister, verb, serving, germ, nerve, clever, artist, sharpen, star, market, farm, shark> <visual: show word spring> <visual: show the sorting cards er and ar in a pocket chart>

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
"er" and "ar" are common word parts at the end of words. They can also be found in the middle of words. You may notice these word parts in many words. As we read, let's look for words with er and ar.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about voting. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. volunteer <pause>, line <pause>, voters <pause>, sign. Look at the people in line in the picture. What do you think they are in line for?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about voting. The word is responsibility. A responsibility is a task that you are required or expected to do.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, responsiblity>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, secure>

audio.transcription: Audio 1: Now listen to “Every Vote Counts!”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words responsiblity and secure>

audio.transcription: Audio 2: Do you have any wonderings or questions about voting? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 9 Student Book. The title of this text is "Let's All Vote!” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Let's All Vote! You will read about how voting gives us the chance to choose who our leaders will be.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: select. To select means “to choose, or make a choice.” At a restaurant, we select the food we want to eat. If you could choose any pet, which animal would you select?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, select>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
What do we pick when we vote in elections?
What kind of government do we have? What happens in a democracy? Find sentences that answer these questions.
What should people think about when they select, or choose, a leader?
What is an issue you care about? How will you decide which leaders to select?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw four boxes on a sheet of paper. <pause> Write an important fact about voting in each box. Use these facts to write a one or two sentence summary of the text. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 9, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 9.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Let’s All Vote!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Audio 1: Listen as I say the following syllables: tur-tle
Audio 2: Repeat the syllables and blend them to make a word. tur-tle, turtle.
Audio 3: Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following syllables. Blend the syllables to make a word.
Audio 1: Now we will segment words into syllables. Listen as I say the following word: turtle
Audio 2: Repeat the word and segment it into the syllables you hear. Turtle, tur-tle.
Audio 3: Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words. Segment each word into the syllables you hear.

This is the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/. The spellings "i-r," "e-r," and "u-r" stand for the /ûr/ sounds. What sounds does the spelling "i-r" make in the word "bird?" <pause> "/ûr/." Listen as your teacher continues with more r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ûr/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: all, away, better, by, change, done, even, found, learn, only.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word all. Say the word with me: "all"
Spell the word with me: a-l-l. The word "all" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: all, away, better, by, change, done, even, found, learn, only.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings. and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word perfect. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word perfect>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: dinner/first, nurse/hurt.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs dinner/first, nurse/hurt>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 9, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 9.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/. The spellings "i-r," "e-r," and "u-r" stand for the /ûr/ sounds. What sounds does the spelling "i-r" make in the word "bird?" <pause> "/ûr/." Listen as your teacher continues with more r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ûr/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: away, all, better, by, change, done, even, found, learn, only.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word away. Say the word with me: "away"
Spell the word with me: a-w-a-y. The word "away" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: all, away, better, by, change, done, even, found, learn, only.

Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. all, <pause> away, <pause> better, <pause> by, <pause> change, <pause> done, <pause> even, <pause> found, <pause> learn, <pause> only.
audio.notes: <visual: show "all, away, better, by, change, done, even, found, learn, only" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.
Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "I want to learn how to ______ ." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "I want to learn how to [blank]." Then show "all, away, better, by, change, done, even, found, learn, only" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for 2nd word>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 9 Student Book. The title of this text is "A Ballot." Point to the word as you read the title with me: A Ballot. When people vote for leaders, they mark their choices on a ballot. This text includes an example of a ballot. Authors include examples to help readers understand the parts of something important to remember.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing the sample ballot?
Create a ballot for a new topic, such as your favorite after-school activity or your favorite ice cream flavor.

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 9, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 9.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Whisper read the text “A Ballot.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

Let's review syllable types. Words are made up of syllables. For example, the words "baker" and "turkey" each have two syllables. Each syllable has one vowel sound. We can use what we know about syllables and spelling patters to read longer words.
Listen as I read the following word: "baker." "Baker" has two syllables: "ba" <pause> "ker."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word baker and the cards ba and ker underneath it>

audio.transcription: The letters "e" and "r" make the /ûr/ sounds in the second syllable.
Listen as I read the following word: "turkey."
Now let's segment the word into syllables. How many syllables are there in the word "turkey?"
The word "turkey" has two syllables. "Tur" <pause> "key."
audio.notes: <visual: show the cards tur and key>

audio.transcription: What letters make the /ûr/ sounds in the first syllable?
The letters "u" and "r" make the /ûr/ sounds.
Practice segmenting the following words into syllables. <pause> Remember, the r-controlled vowel spelling stays in the same syllable.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words: party, yogurt, burger, sister, target, return, surfer>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/. The spellings "i-r," "e-r," and "u-r" stand for the /ûr/ sounds. What sounds does the spelling "i-r" make in the word "bird?" <pause> "/ûr/." Listen as your teacher continues with more r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ûr/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with ur.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with -ful.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word hem. <pause> Change r to m and make the r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spelling. What word did you make? Her
audio.notes: <visual: show letter cards to build words>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word hem <pause>. Now change hem to her. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about presidential pets. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. White House <pause>, lawn <pause>, dog <pause>, Oval Office <pause>, cat. Look at the dog in the picture. Where is this dog?

Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about presidential pets. The word is impressive. If someone or something is impressive, it deserves respect because of its great size, quality, or skill.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, impressive>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, companions>

audio.transcription: Audio 1: Now listen to “Presidential Pets”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words impressive and companions>

audio.transcription: Audio 2: Do you have any wonderings or questions about presidential pets? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 9 Student Book. The title of this story is "The New Guy.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The New Guy. You will read a story about a boy who visits his dad at the firehouse.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: companion. A companion is a person or animal someone spends a lot of time with. Your best friend is a companion. Who is your favorite companion?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, companion>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that names the job Turner’s dad has.
How did the new “guy” end up at the firehouse? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Why do you think the firefighters chose to keep the kitten as a companion? Do you think a kitten makes a good companion at a firehouse? Why or why not?
Which animal would you choose to be your companion at home?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw a picture to remember the important details in the story. <pause> Label the details, such as Dad, Tyler, kitten, firehouse, and water hoses. <pause> Use your drawing to retell the story to a partner. Then, write your retelling.

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 9, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 9.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The New Guy.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/. The spellings "i-r," "e-r," and "u-r" stand for the /ûr/ sounds. What sounds does the spelling "i-r" make in the word "bird?" <pause> "/ûr/." Listen as your teacher continues with more r-controlled vowel /ûr/ spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-controlled vowel /ûr/>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word hurt.
Now write the word third.
Finally, write this sentence: Is that some dirt on your shirt?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about Washington, D.C. becoming the capital of the United States. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Washington Monument <pause>, dome <pause>, Capitol <pause>, National Mall. Look at the dome in the picture. What is the dome attached to?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about Washington, D.C. becoming the capital of the United States. The word is memorial. A memorial is a structure that honors a person or event.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, memorial>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, elaborate>

audio.transcription: Audio 1: Now listen to “The United States Capital”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words memorial and elaborate>

audio.transcription: Audio 2: Do you have any wonderings or questions about Washington, D.C. becoming the capital of the United States? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 9 Student Book. The title of this text is "The President's House.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The President's House. This is an informational text that gives facts about where the president of the United States lives.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: unusual. Unusual means “not usual, or not common.” A tiger would be an unusual thing to see at school, but not at a zoo. What things would be unusual to see inside a classroom?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, unusual>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that names the place in the White House to watch movies.
How can you tell the White House is very large? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why can we say that some White House pets were quite unusual?
What else would you like to know about the White House? Why?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a list of interesting facts to show why people might want to visit the White House. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 9, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 9.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 9 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The President’s House.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Listen as I say a word: ray
Say the word ray, but change the beginning sound. Change /r/, to /m/. What's the new word? <pause> may
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: bend
Say the word bend, but change the ending sound. Change /d/, to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> bent
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the middle sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: pan
Say the word pan, but change the middle sound. Change /a/, to /ā/. What's the new word? <pause> pain
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

Let's review syllable types. R-controlled vowel syllables have an r-controlled vowel. The letters that make up the r-controlled vowel spelling stay together in the same syllable. The words "dinner," "disturb," and "circus" all have an r-controlled vowel syllable.
Listen as I read the following word: "dinner." How many syllables are there in the word "dinner?"
The word "dinner" has two syllables. "din" <pause> "ner." The letters "e" and "r" make the /ûr/ sounds in the second syllable.
Listen as I read the following word: "disturb." How many syllables are there in the word "disturb?"
The word "disturb" has two syllables. "dis" <pause> "turb." The letters "u" and "r" make the /ûr/ sounds in the second syllable.
Listen as I read the following word: "circus." How many syllables are there in the word "circus?"
The word "circus" has two syllables. "cir" <pause> "cus." The letters "i" and "r" make the /ûr/ sounds in the first syllable.
Practice dividing the following words into syllables and then identifying the r-controlled vowel spelling in each word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words after, surprise, birthday, perfect, letter, sunburn, garden>

audio.transcription: Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
This word names a body part on a fish.
Change one letter in fin to name a word that describes clothes that are the right size.
Add one letter in fit to make a word that names what you make when you hold your hand tightly.
Add one letter to fist to name the place the fastest runner in a race finishes.
Change the beginning of first to name a word that means “a need for water.”
Change the ending of thirst to name what comes after second.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: all, away, better, by, change, done, even, found, learn, only>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "better."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: better>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 9!
